Generation I.Red: The tentacles are normally kept short. On hunts, they are extended to ensnare and immobilize prey.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: The tentacles are normally kept short. On hunts, they are extended to ensnare and immobilize prey.
Generation I.Yellow: Its 80 tentacles can stretch and contract freely. They wrap around prey and weaken it with poison.
Generation I.Stadium: It has 80 tentacles. Once they wrap around an enemy, the tentacles will not release, no matter what.

Generation II.Gold: Its 80 tentacles absorb water and stretch almost endlessly to Constrict its prey and enemies.
Generation II.Silver: In battle, it extends all 80 of its tentacles to entrap its opponent inside a poisonous net.
Generation II.Crystal: When its 80 feelers absorb water, it stretches to become like a net to entangle its prey.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Its 80 tentacles absorb water and stretch almost endlessly to Constrict its prey and enemies. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) In battle, it extends all 80 of its tentacles to entrap its opponent inside a poisonous net. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Tentacruel has large red orbs on its head. The orbs glow before lashing the vicinity with a harsh ultrasonic blast. This Pok é mon 's outburst creates rough waves around it.
Generation III.Sapphire: Tentacruel has tentacles that can be freely elongated and shortened at will. It ensnares prey with its tentacles and weakens the prey by dosing it with a harsh toxin. It can catch up to 80 prey at the same time.
Generation III.Emerald: It lives in complex rock formations on the ocean floor and traps prey using its 80 tentacles. Its red orbs glow when it grows excited or agitated.
Generation III.FireRed: It has 80 tentacles that move about freely. They can sting, causing poisoning and sharp, stabbing pain.
Generation III.LeafGreen: The tentacles are normally kept short. On hunts, they are extended to ensnare and immobilize prey.

Generation IV.Diamond: With 80 tentacles for ensnaring victims, it prevents escape until the prey is weakened by poison.
Generation IV.Pearl: It alerts others to danger by stridently flashing the red orbs on its head.
Generation IV.Platinum: It extends its 80 tentacles to form an encircling poisonous net that is difficult to escape.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Its 80 tentacles absorb water and stretch almost endlessly to constrict its prey and enemies.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: In battle, it extends all 80 of its tentacles to entrap its opponent inside a poisonous net.

Generation V.Black: It extends its 80 tentacles to form an encircling poisonous net that is difficult to escape.
Generation V.White: It extends its 80 tentacles to form an encircling poisonous net that is difficult to escape.
Generation V.Black 2: It extends its 80 tentacles to form an encircling poisonous net that is difficult to escape.
Generation V.White 2: It extends its 80 tentacles to form an encircling poisonous net that is difficult to escape.

Generation VI.X: The tentacles are normally kept short. On hunts, they are extended to ensnare and immobilize prey.
Generation VI.Y: It has 80 tentacles that move about freely. They can sting, causing poisoning and sharp, stabbing pain.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Tentacruel has large red orbs on its head. The orbs glow before lashing the vicinity with a harsh ultrasonic blast. This Pokémon's outburst creates rough waves around it.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Tentacruel has tentacles that can be freely elongated and shortened at will. It ensnares prey with its tentacles and weakens the prey by dosing it with a harsh toxin. It can catch up to 80 prey at the same time.

Generation VII.Sun: Normally, it has 80 poisonous tentacles. The longer one has been alive, the fewer tentacles it will have.
Generation VII.Moon: Although these Pokémon are rare, when a large outbreak of them occurs, all fish Pokémon disappear from the surrounding sea.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: It fires off ultrasonic waves from its red orbs to weaken its prey, and then it wraps them up in its 80 tentacles.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: It communicates with others of its kind by lighting up the red orbs on its head. When the orbs are blinking, it's a warning sign.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Its 80 tentacles can stretch and contract freely. They wrap around prey and weaken it with poison.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Its 80 tentacles can stretch and contract freely. They wrap around prey and weaken it with poison.

Generation VIII.Sword: When the red orbs on Tentacruel's head glow brightly, watch out. The Pokémon is about to fire off a burst of ultrasonic waves.
Generation VIII.Shield: Its 80 tentacles can stretch and shrink freely. Tentacruel ensnares prey in a net of spread-out tentacles, delivering venomous stings to its catch.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: With 80 tentacles for ensnaring victims, it prevents escape until the prey is weakened by poison.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It alerts others to danger by stridently flashing the red orbs on its head.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: It has 80 tentacles, each with a venomous tip. These tentacles are also extendible, lengthening when Tentacruel attempts to catch prey. Use caution.

Generation IX.Scarlet: On the rare occasions that large outbreaks of Tentacruel occur, all fish Pokémon disappear from the surrounding sea.
Generation IX.Violet: In battle, it extends all 80 of its tentacles to entrap its opponent inside a poisonous net.
